April 1917.SECRET.Qu.WAR CABINET, 113.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10, Downing Street, on Wednesday,April 4, 1917, at 11*30 a.m.Present:The Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. A. Henderson, M.P.The Right Hon. A. Bonar Law, M.P.The Right Hon. the Earl Curzon kedleston, KG., G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E.The Right Hon. the Viscount Milner,- G.C.B., G.C.M.G.The following were also present: The Right Hon. A. J. balfour, O.M.,M.P., Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. the Lord Hardinge of penshurst, KG, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.,G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., G.C.V.O., I.S.O.,Permanent Under-Secretary of State forForeign Affairs (for Minutes 1 to 20).The Right Hon. the Earl of Derbt, K.G.,G.C.V.O., C.B., Secretary of State forWar (for Minutes 1 to 14).General Sir W. R. Robertson, G.C.B.,K.C.V.O., D.S.O., Chief of the ImperialGeneral Staff (for Minutes 1 to 14).The Right Hon. The Lord R. Cecil,K.C., M.P., Minister of Blockade (for minutes 19 and 21).Admiral Sir J. R. Jellicoe, G.C.B.,O.M., G.C.V.O., First Sea Lord of theAdmiralty (for Minutes 1 to 14).Lieutenant-Colonel Sir M. P. A. Hankey, K.C.B., Secretary.Fleet Paymaster P. H. Row, R.N., Assistant Secretary.Captain Clement Jones, Assistant Secretary.The Abolition ofthe Trade CardScheme.1. Mr. HENDERSON reported that, as the result of theconference with representatives of the Trade Unions on theprevious day, there appeared good prospect that the abolition ofthe Trade Cards would be agreed to. He understood that aCommittee had been appointed to consider in further detail theschedule of trades exempted.The Hedjaz.2. With reference to Imperial War Cabinet 7, Minute 3, theChief of the Imperial General Staff reported that the Arabs weredisplaying further activity north of Medina in the destruction ofthe railway.Mesopotamia. 3. The Chief of the Imperial General Staff reported thatGeneral Maude had established touch with the Russians. His patrols were in touch with theirs, and our aeroplanes had visited the Russian headquarters. According to a telegram received at theForeign Office, the Russians are in Khanikin.Turkish Troops. 4. The Chief of the Imperial General Staff reported that theTurks were concentrating a good many Divisions in Asia Minors-One Division was reported to be arriving at Damascus, while only'six or seven Turkish Divisions were now left in Europe.Italy- 5. With reference to War Cabinet, 109, Minute 5 (a), the, Chief of the Imperial General Staff reported that the heavy gunspromised to Italy would begin to leave for Italy within a few days,and would arrive in time for the operations planned by general cadorna, of which he gave the latest particulars.Salonica. 6. The War Cabinet had a short preliminary discussion as tothe possible effects of withdrawing a portion of the forces based onSalonica to reinforce the Palestine Expedition. Reference wasmade to the suggestion contained in Colonel Plunkett's report, datedthe 31st March, 1917, that, after a partially successful offensive, anopportunity might occur for coming to terms with Bulgaria, and tothe Memorandum of the Chief of the Imperial General Staff, datedthe 2nd April, 1917, raising the question of the policy of theSalonica Expedition.It was agreed that No final decision could betaken on these questions until further operations had taken place in this region.Mount Athos: 7. The Secretary of State for War undertook to telegraph to proposed General Milne as to the possibility of developing hospital andInstallation- of sanatorium accommodation on Mount Athos, with a view toHospitals. reducing the great demand for hospital ships, which must beanticipated when the hot weather sets in, particularly if the enemyextends the policy of attacking hospital ships with submarines.Submarines.8. The Eirst Sea Lord reported the sinking of a mine-sweepinggunboat, and made his usual statement of mercantile casualties.Heligoland.9. The Eirst Sea Lord undertook to circulate to the imperial war Cabinet the replies of the Admirals to questions, addressed tothem by Mr. Balfour when he was Eirst Lord, in regard toHeligoland.Shipping: 10. The Prime Minister supplied the following figures in regardMerchant to new construction between now and February next, supplied byShipbuilding. tlle shipping ControllerGross Tons.850,000312,000720,0001,882,000Building in the United KingdomBuilding abroadGerman Shipping in American PortsThere was some difference of opinion as to how far these figures could be taken as reassuring or otherwise. Some stress was laid on the fact that every ship in Naval and Military service cnatwas sunk had to be replaced by withdrawing a ship from civilianservices.The general view was that, though serious, the figures beforethe War Cabinet did not support the theory that we should be compelled, by our shipping shortage, to make peace this year,provided that the Government policy of restricted imports and increased production is carried out.Lord Derby stated that he was holding a Conference that afternoon with the Shipping Controller with a view to a reductionin the military demands on shipping.With reference to Imperial War Cabinet, 4, Minute 5, he reported that the War Office were making enquiries into the possi-bility of increasing hospital accommodation in France..11. The War Cabinet took note of the Memorandum by theFirst Sea Lord entitled " The Effects of the Revolution on theSituation in the Baltic."The Situation inthe Baltic.12. The War Cabinet authorised The Secretary of State for War, in concert with the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs, to make enquiries with a viewto carrying out the proposals contained in telegramNo. 803, dated the 3rd April, 1917, from The Hague, that russian Poles and Austrian Jews now in Holland shouldbe brought here for lumber and agricultural work in theUnited Kingdom. The War Cabinet, however, laid stress on the importance of taking adequate precautions forguarding against the introduction of spies.The United Statesof America. 13. With reference to Imperial War Cabinet, 7, Minute 1, theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs gave some account of had discussions with the American Ambassador. Mr. Page had welcomed the idea of a visit to the Hnited States of America by arepresentative of the British Government, but had indicated that little was required from the point of view of stimulating publicopinion. What was required was an exchange of views as tothe nature of the co-operation of the United States of America.In this connection a telegram was read from Mr. PomeroyBurton to Lord Northcliffe, laying stress on the importance of theearly despatch of experts in war organisation of all kinds to confer with American experts.The War Cabinet considered that it was of great importance that, in order to initiate the expert negotiations, someone of thehighest status in this country, who was known to the american people, and who would have the entree to all circles, should proceedto Washington.Mr. Balfour undertook to inform Mr. Page in the afternoon.Subject to a favourable reply from the United States Govern-ment before the actual departure, the War Cabinet decided that . All preparations should he made by the Admiralty for the departure of the selected representative at a very earlydate. He should be accompanied by Employment of austrian Jews nowin Holland.Representatives of the Admiralty, to be nominated bythe First Lord ; Hospital Ships:Reprisals.14. With reference to Imperial War Cabinet, 7, Minute 7,the War Cabinet authorised, the First Lord, of the Admiralty toascertain, from the French whether they could co-operate with our aircraft, in the event of a decision to take reprisals for the sinking of hospital ships, in the form of aerial attack on open towns.The Recent mission to Russia:Central Council of allies.15. The War Cabinet take note of Resolution 5, passed at therecent Conference at Petrograd, referred to. in Lord MilneFsmemorandum of the 13th March, 1917 [G-131].Lord Milner explained that the intention had been that these conferences should preferably be informal in character, and held,not at a capital city, but at some quiet spot; not at regular intervals, but whenever the course of the War seemed to call forthem, and that they should be attended as a rule by the Heads ofthe several Governments, though the choice should not be limitedto the actual Prime Ministers, each Ally deciding on its representa-tion according to the subject for discussion; and that a Russianrepresentative of very high status should be selected to reside in western Europe and to speak for the Russian Government at theirConferences. The War Cabinet decided To ratify this resolution, and the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs undertook to inform the French andItalian Governments of this decision, and to. ask if they proposed to do the same.It was decided To postpone any communication to the Russian government until the political situation in that country was moresettled. ,The War Cabinet placed on record the expression of theirthanks to Lord Milner and the other British Representatives at the petrograd Conference.Russia:Supply ofMunitions.16. The War Cabinet sanctioned The continuance of the Committee already sitting under LordMilnePs presidency, composed of representatives of theTreasury, Admiralty, War Office, Ministry of Munitions,Ministry of Shipping, and Commission.Internationale deRavitaillement, to examine and decide upon Russianapplications for assistance in accordance with the decisionof the Petrograd Conference.Management of rail-ways..17. With reference to a telegram from Washington, No. 856,the War Cabinet authorised The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs to telegraph to theBritish Ambassador at Petrograd to enquire whether the* At the discretion of the Food Controller.Representatives of the War Office, to be nominated by the Secretary of State for War;A Representative of the Minister of Shipping;A Representative of the Minister of Food* ; *A Representative of the Minister of Munitions ;The Governor of the Bank of England.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs undertook to informthe. French Government of the. above decision. Russian Government would allow the management of theirrailways, including the Siberian Railway, to be taken overby American experts.Eoumania: 18. The Secretary brought before the War Cabinet a letterHeavy Artillery. from the Roumanian Minister to the Prime Minister urging the* supply of heavy artillery for the Roumanian Army.Having regard to the uncertain situation on the Eastern Eront,the great demands on transport, due to the size of the Russianrequirements, and the doubtful military value of the RoumanianArmy, the War Cabinet considered that-The moment was not opportune for consideration of thisquestion.Holland: 19. The Minister of Blockade reported that the Dutch Govern-Food Shortage ment had announced that the food shortage in Holland was due tothe fault of the British Government in holding up steamers, andthat the British Minister at The Hague had very properly corn-plained to the Dutch Government of their attitude in the matter,pointing out that a great part of the delay was due to the Germans.The War Cabinet decided that A telegram should be sent to the British Minister at TheHague, informing him that the Dutch Government mustapologise in the newspapers and correct their communiquein which they complained that their food shortage was caused by the British Government.If the Dutch Government retract their statement, the BritishGovernment will then allow all food ships to proceed fromHalifax and not insist upon their calling at Kirkwall.Requisitioning of dutch Ships.20. In view of the fact that the Dutch ships now detained in our ports, if released, would probably be merely laid up in Dutch ports,a procedure which is inadmissible in the present shipping situation,the War Cabinet authorised The Minister of Blockade to continue for the present to detainthese ships, in the hope that eventually the owners might agree to charter them to us.The United States 21. The Minister of Blockade reported that the United Statesof America: Ambassador had asked us to withdraw the Statutory Black List, and statutory Black that M. Cochin, the Erench Minister of Blockade, had intimatedList- that he had no objection. The War Cabinet authorised The Minister of Blockade to comply with the request of theAmerican Ambassador.(Initialled) D. LI. G.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.,April 4, 1917.o
